rules: Rule1: If a food product requires inspection for basic safety, then it is approved for sale.
Rule2: A food product being approved for sale is guaranteed if it meets the standard for the premium mark.
Rule3: Whenever a food product gets suspended, it gets an investigation.

Rule4: Given that a food product has contamination, then if it is not the case that not meeting the standard for the quality mark implies approval for sale leads to not getting a recall, it gets suspended.
Rule5: A forced recall of a food product ensures that it does not get a voluntary recall.
Rule6: Should a food product require inspection for advanced safety, it is approved for sale.
Rule7: If a food product causes illness, then market rejection entails that it does not get market approval.
Rule8: A food product causing hospitalization implies that it causes illness.
Rule9: Whenever a food product causes death, it causes hospitalization.
Rule10: If a food product gets a national ban, it gets an international ban.
Rule11: A food product gets a ban provided that it gets an international ban.
Rule12: If a food product gets a review, then it gets temporary approval.
Rule13: A food product getting a hearing implies it gets a review.
Rule14: Either a manufacturer files an appeal or it accepts the decision.
Rule15: Provided that a manufacturer accepts the decision, then temporary rejection of the food product leads to it getting a hearing.
Rule16: A manufacturer winning an appeal entails that if it files an appeal, then temporary rejection of the food product results in it getting a hearing.
Rule17: A manufacturer either wins an appeal or loses an appeal.
Rule18: If a manufacturer loses an appeal, then filing an appeal implies that temporary rejection of the food product leads to it getting a hearing.
Rule19: A manufacturer paying compensation leads to it facing trial.
Rule20: Either a manufacturer pays compensation or it denies liability.
Rule21: A manufacturer denying liability means that either it has insurance coverage or an outbreak in the food product causes hospitalization.
Rule22: If a manufacturer settles a lawsuit, then either it has insurance coverage or an outbreak in the food product causes hospitalization.
Rule23: A manufacturer facing trial implies that it settles a lawsuit.
Rule24: A food product either has approval from the regulatory body or has rejection from the regulatory body.
Rule25: Provided that a food product has rejection from the regulatory body, then not requiring inspection for basic safety or advanced safety results in it getting an exemption from inspection.

Rule26: If a manufacturer passes an audit by the regulatory body, then if not having approval from the regulatory body implies that not requiring inspection for basic safety or advanced safety leads to an exemption from inspection, the food product gets emergency clearance.
Rule27: Either a manufacturer passes an audit by the regulatory body or it fails an audit by the regulatory body.

Rule28: A manufacturer failing an audit by the regulatory body entails that if not having approval from the regulatory body implies that not requiring inspection for basic safety or advanced safety leads to an exemption from inspection, the food product gets emergency clearance.
Rule29: A food product either meets the standard for the quality mark or meets the standard for the premium mark.
Rule30: Not requiring inspection for basic safety or advanced safety implies that the food product does not get an exemption from inspection.
Rule31: Provided that it is not the case that market rejection implies not getting market approval, the food product gets temporary rejection.
Rule32: Whenever it is not the case that market rejection implies not getting market approval, the food product does not get temporary approval.
Rule33: Given that it is not the case that an outbreak implies causing illness, the food product gets a national ban.
Rule34: Should it not be the case that an outbreak implies causing death, the food product gets limited distribution.

Rule35: Provided that it is not the case that having approval from the regulatory body implies that not requiring inspection for basic safety or advanced safety leads to an exemption from inspection, the food product does not get emergency clearance.
Rule36: If it is not the case that meeting the standard for the quality mark implies approval for sale, then the food product gets a recall.
Rule37: Provided that it is not the case that not meeting the standard for the quality mark implies approval for sale leads to not getting a recall, the food product does not get an investigation.
Rule38: A food product not having contamination leads to it getting a voluntary recall.
Rule39: If a food product does not have contamination, it gets a forced recall.
Rule40: A food product not being approved for sale leads to it getting market approval.
Rule41: If a food product is not approved for sale, it gets market rejection.
facts: Fact1: A food product has an outbreak.
Fact2: A food product does not get limited distribution.
Fact3: A food product does not get a ban.
Fact4: A manufacturer does not have insurance coverage.

question: A food product is approved for sale.
